nodes.label: Gabriel García Márquez
nodes.description: Colombian novelist, a leading figure of the Magical Realism movement.

nodes.label: One Hundred Years of Solitude
nodes.description: A multi-generational story of the Buendía family, whose patriarch founds the town of Macondo.

nodes.label: Isabel Allende
nodes.description: Chilean writer whose works often contain aspects of the magical realist tradition.

nodes.label: The House of the Spirits
nodes.description: Details the life of the Trueba family in a sweeping family saga.

nodes.label: Salman Rushdie
nodes.description: British-American novelist whose work combines magical realism with historical fiction.

nodes.label: Midnight's Children
nodes.description: Deals with India's transition from British colonialism to independence, linked by telepathic children.

nodes.label: Haruki Murakami
nodes.description: Japanese writer whose work blends the mundane with the surreal and fantastical.

nodes.label: Kafka on the Shore
nodes.description: An intricate novel with two distinct but interrelated plots, featuring talking cats and fish falling from the sky.

nodes.label: Jorge Luis Borges
nodes.description: Argentine short-story writer, a key figure in Spanish-language literature and a precursor to magical realism.

nodes.label: Ficciones
nodes.description: A collection of short stories exploring themes of labyrinths, dreams, and infinity.

nodes.label: Laura Esquivel
nodes.description: Mexican novelist known for her use of magical realism in the context of cooking and romance.

nodes.label: Like Water for Chocolate
nodes.description: A novel where the protagonist's emotions are infused into the food she cooks, affecting those who eat it.

nodes.label: Toni Morrison
nodes.description: American novelist whose works often feature elements of myth, magic, and the supernatural in African-American history.

nodes.label: Beloved
nodes.description: A novel inspired by the story of an enslaved African-American woman, Margaret Garner, exploring the haunting legacy of slavery.

nodes.label: Julio Cortázar
nodes.description: An Argentine-French novelist, one of the founders of the Latin American Boom.

nodes.label: Hopscotch
nodes.description: An experimental novel that can be read in multiple sequences, challenging the traditional linear narrative.

nodes.label: Günter Grass
nodes.description: German novelist and Nobel laureate whose work often incorporates fantastical elements.

nodes.label: The Tin Drum
nodes.description: The story of Oskar Matzerath, who decides to stop growing at age three, told from his unique perspective.

nodes.label: Angela Carter
nodes.description: English novelist known for her feminist, magical realism, and picaresque works.

nodes.label: Nights at the Circus
nodes.description: A story of a winged circus performer in the 19th century, blending fantasy and reality.

nodes.label: Mikhail Bulgakov
nodes.description: Russian writer whose work satirized Soviet society with surreal and fantastical elements.

nodes.label: The Master and Margarita
nodes.description: A novel that intertwines the Devil's visit to Moscow with the story of Pontius Pilate and Jesus Christ.

nodes.label: Alejo Carpentier
nodes.description: A Cuban novelist who profoundly influenced Latin American literature, coining the term 'lo real maravilloso' (the marvelous real).

nodes.label: The Kingdom of this World
nodes.description: A novel about the Haitian Revolution, blending history with Afro-Caribbean mythology and folklore.

nodes.label: Miguel Ángel Asturias
nodes.description: A Guatemalan Nobel laureate whose work was deeply influenced by Mayan mythology.

nodes.label: Men of Maize
nodes.description: A novel that explores the conflict between indigenous traditions and modernizing forces in Guatemala.

nodes.label: Ben Okri
nodes.description: A Nigerian poet and novelist who uses magical realism to explore post-colonial themes.

nodes.label: The Famished Road
nodes.description: The story of Azaro, a spirit-child, navigating the harsh realities of life in Nigeria.

nodes.label: Yasunari Kawabata
nodes.description: A Japanese novelist and the first Japanese author to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature.

nodes.label: Palm-of-the-Hand Stories
nodes.description: A collection of very short stories that often blend reality with dreamlike and surreal imagery.

nodes.label: Milan Kundera
nodes.description: A Czech-born French writer whose novels often weave together philosophical reflection with a touch of the absurd and surreal.

nodes.label: The Unbearable Lightness of Being
nodes.description: A novel about two women, two men, a dog, and their lives in the 1968 Prague Spring.

nodes.label: Mo Yan
nodes.description: A Chinese novelist and Nobel laureate known for his 'hallucinatory realism'.

nodes.label: Red Sorghum
nodes.description: A family saga set in a rural part of China during the Second Sino-Japanese War.

nodes.label: Italo Calvino
nodes.description: An Italian writer whose work often takes the form of fables and explores fantastical possibilities.

nodes.label: Invisible Cities
nodes.description: A novel structured as a conversation between Marco Polo and Kublai Khan, describing 55 fantastical cities.

nodes.label: Alice Hoffman
nodes.description: American novelist known for weaving magic and the supernatural into contemporary settings.

nodes.label: Practical Magic
nodes.description: A story about two witch sisters who must use their powers to overcome a family curse.

nodes.label: Sarah Addison Allen
nodes.description: American author whose novels are often set in the Southern United States and feature magical elements.

nodes.label: Garden Spells
nodes.description: A story of the Waverley family, whose magical apple tree bears fruit with special properties.

nodes.label: Aimee Bender
nodes.description: An American writer known for her surrealist, fairytale-like short stories and novels.

nodes.label: The Particular Sadness of Lemon Cake
nodes.description: A novel about a young girl who can taste the emotions of the person who prepared her food.

nodes.label: Helen Oyeyemi
nodes.description: A British novelist whose work often reinterprets fairy tales with a modern, surreal twist.

nodes.label: Boy, Snow, Bird
nodes.description: A retelling of Snow White set in 1950s America, exploring themes of race and identity.

nodes.label: Nnedi Okorafor
nodes.description: A Nigerian-American writer of science fiction and fantasy, often blending Africanfuturism with magical elements.

nodes.label: Who Fears Death
nodes.description: A post-apocalyptic novel set in Sudan, following a young woman with magical powers.

nodes.label: Kelly Link
nodes.description: An American author of speculative fiction and magical realism short stories.

nodes.label: Get in Trouble
nodes.description: A collection of short stories that blend the mundane with the fantastic and surreal.

nodes.label: Carmen Maria Machado
nodes.description: An American writer whose work often incorporates elements of horror, fantasy, and magical realism.

nodes.label: Her Body and Other Parties
nodes.description: A collection of short stories that uses fabulism to explore the realities of women's lives.

nodes.label: Kazuo Ishiguro
nodes.description: A British novelist and Nobel laureate whose works often have a subtle, unsettling sense of unreality.

nodes.label: The Buried Giant
nodes.description: A fantasy novel set in Arthurian Britain, where a strange mist causes mass amnesia.

nodes.label: Lesley Nneka Arimah
nodes.description: A Nigerian writer whose short stories blend magical realism with Nigerian folklore.

nodes.label: What It Means When a Man Falls from the Sky
nodes.description: A collection of stories that explore the lives of Nigerian women through a fabulist lens.

nodes.label: Silvia Moreno-Garcia
nodes.description: A Mexican-Canadian author who often blends genres, including fantasy, horror, and magical realism.

nodes.label: Mexican Gothic
nodes.description: A gothic horror novel set in 1950s Mexico, featuring a remote mansion with a dark secret.

nodes.label: Jeanette Winterson
nodes.description: A British writer whose novels often blend reality with myth, fairytale, and history.

nodes.label: The Passion
nodes.description: A historical novel set during the Napoleonic Wars, featuring a web-footed Venetian woman.

nodes.label: Erin Morgenstern
nodes.description: An American author known for her fantastical and magical novels.

nodes.label: The Night Circus
nodes.description: A fantasy novel about a magical competition between two young illusionists.

nodes.label: Tea Obreht
nodes.description: A Serbian-American novelist whose work incorporates folklore and myth.

nodes.label: The Tiger's Wife
nodes.description: A novel that weaves together the story of a young doctor in the Balkans with the myths her grandfather told her.

nodes.label: Yoko Ogawa
nodes.description: A Japanese writer whose work often has a surreal, dreamlike quality.

nodes.label: The Housekeeper and the Professor
nodes.description: A novel about a brilliant mathematician whose memory only lasts for eighty minutes.

nodes.label: Patrick Süskind
nodes.description: A German writer and screenwriter, known for his fantastical and obsessive characters.

nodes.label: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer
nodes.description: A historical fantasy novel about a man with an exceptional sense of smell who attempts to create the world's finest perfume.

nodes.label: Jonathan Safran Foer
nodes.description: An American novelist known for his experimental and emotionally resonant work.

nodes.label: Everything Is Illuminated
nodes.description: A novel that tells the story of a young Jewish-American man who goes to Ukraine to find the woman who saved his grandfather from the Nazis.

nodes.label: Mark Helprin
nodes.description: An American novelist and journalist, known for his fantastical and epic narratives.

nodes.label: Winter's Tale
nodes.description: A fantasy novel set in a mythical version of New York City.

nodes.label: Karen Russell
nodes.description: An American novelist and short story writer, known for her surreal and imaginative stories set in Florida.

nodes.label: Swamplandia!
nodes.description: A novel about a family of alligator wrestlers in the Florida Everglades.

nodes.label: China Miéville
nodes.description: An English fantasy fiction author, associated with the 'New Weird' genre.

nodes.label: Perdido Street Station
nodes.description: A fantasy novel set in the sprawling, steampunk city of New Crobuzon.

nodes.label: Jeff VanderMeer
nodes.description: An American author, editor, and literary critic, known for his work in the New Weird genre.

nodes.label: Annihilation
nodes.description: The first book in the Southern Reach Trilogy, about a team of scientists who enter a mysterious, quarantined zone.

nodes.label: Neil Gaiman
nodes.description: An English author of short fiction, novels, comic books, graphic novels, nonfiction, audio theatre, and films.

nodes.label: American Gods
nodes.description: A fantasy novel that blends Americana, fantasy, and various strands of ancient and modern mythology.

nodes.label: Susanna Clarke
nodes.description: An English author known for her debut novel Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell.

nodes.label: Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell
nodes.description: An alternative history set in 19th-century England, where magic has returned.

nodes.label: N. K. Jemisin
nodes.description: An American science fiction and fantasy writer.

nodes.label: The Fifth Season
nodes.description: A science fantasy novel set on a planet with a single supercontinent that suffers from catastrophic climate change every few centuries.

nodes.label: Ursula K. Le Guin
nodes.description: An American author known for her works of speculative fiction, including science fiction works set in her Hainish universe, and the Earthsea fantasy series.

nodes.label: A Wizard of Earthsea
nodes.description: A fantasy novel that is the first of the Earthsea series, following a young wizard named Ged.

nodes.label: Carlos Fuentes
nodes.description: A Mexican novelist and essayist, and one of the most admired writers in the Spanish-speaking world.

nodes.label: The Death of Artemio Cruz
nodes.description: A novel that portrays the life of a dying Mexican tycoon, reflecting on his past and the history of modern Mexico.

nodes.label: Mario Vargas Llosa
nodes.description: A Peruvian novelist, journalist, essayist, and former politician, who is one of Latin America's most significant novelists and a Nobel laureate.

nodes.label: Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter
nodes.description: A semi-autobiographical novel based on the author's own life, about a young writer and his relationship with his aunt and a radio scriptwriter.

nodes.label: José Saramago
nodes.description: A Portuguese writer and recipient of the 1998 Nobel Prize in Literature.

nodes.label: Blindness
nodes.description: A novel about a mass epidemic of blindness that plagues an unnamed city.

nodes.label: W. G. Sebald
nodes.description: A German writer and academic whose works blend fiction, history, and travelogue.

nodes.label: The Emigrants
nodes.description: A novel that tells the stories of four German emigrants, blurring the line between fact and fiction.

nodes.label: Olga Tokarczuk
nodes.description: A Polish writer and activist, and a Nobel laureate, whose work often explores myth, history, and folklore.

nodes.label: Flights
nodes.description: A fragmentary novel that meditates on travel and human anatomy.

nodes.label: Juan Rulfo
nodes.description: A Mexican writer, screenwriter, and photographer, known for his two seminal works, 'El Llano en llamas' and the novel 'Pedro Páramo'.

nodes.label: Pedro Páramo
nodes.description: A short novel that tells the story of a man who travels to his mother's hometown to find his father, only to find a town populated by ghosts.

nodes.label: Clarice Lispector
nodes.description: A Brazilian novelist and short story writer, known for her innovative and existentialist works.

nodes.label: The Hour of the Star
nodes.description: A novel about a poor, uneducated woman in Rio de Janeiro, exploring themes of poverty, identity, and existence.

nodes.label: Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o
nodes.description: A Kenyan writer and academic who writes primarily in Gikuyu.

nodes.label: Wizard of the Crow
nodes.description: A satirical novel set in a fictional African country, exploring themes of politics, corruption, and power.

nodes.label: Amos Tutuola
nodes.description: A Nigerian writer who wrote in English. He is best known for his novel The Palm-Wine Drinkard.

nodes.label: The Palm-Wine Drinkard
nodes.description: A novel that follows a man who journeys to the land of the dead to find his deceased palm-wine tapster.

nodes.label: Ismail Kadare
nodes.description: An Albanian novelist, poet, essayist, and playwright.

nodes.label: The Palace of Dreams
nodes.description: A novel set in the Ottoman Empire, about a bureaucratic institution that collects and interprets the dreams of the empire's citizens.

nodes.label: William Faulkner
nodes.description: An American writer and Nobel Prize laureate from Oxford, Mississippi. Faulkner wrote novels, short stories, screenplays, poetry, essays, and a play.

nodes.label: As I Lay Dying
nodes.description: A 1930 novel in the stream of consciousness style by William Faulkner.

nodes.label: Eowyn Ivey
nodes.description: An American author known for her novels set in Alaska, which often incorporate elements of fairy tales.

nodes.label: The Snow Child
nodes.description: A novel based on a Russian fairy tale, about a childless couple in Alaska who build a child out of snow.

nodes.label: Alix E. Harrow
nodes.description: An American writer of science fiction and fantasy.

nodes.label: The Ten Thousand Doors of January
nodes.description: A fantasy novel about a young woman who discovers a mysterious book that leads her to a world of magic and adventure.

nodes.label: Shaun Tan
nodes.description: An Australian artist, writer and film maker. He won an Academy Award for The Lost Thing, a 2011 animated film adaptation of a 2000 picture book of the same name.

nodes.label: The Arrival
nodes.description: A wordless graphic novel that depicts the story of an immigrant in a surreal, dreamlike city.

nodes.label: Andrei Bely
nodes.description: A Russian novelist, Symbolist poet, and literary theorist.

nodes.label: Petersburg
nodes.description: A modernist novel that is considered a masterpiece of Symbolist prose.

nodes.label: Alfred Kubin
nodes.description: An Austrian printmaker, illustrator, and occasional writer. Kubin is considered an important representative of Symbolism and Expressionism.

nodes.label: The Other Side
nodes.description: A fantastical novel about a dream kingdom that becomes a nightmare.

nodes.label: Leonora Carrington
nodes.description: A British-born surrealist painter, novelist, and short story writer.

nodes.label: The Hearing Trumpet
nodes.description: A surrealist novel about a 92-year-old woman who is sent to a mysterious retirement home.

nodes.label: Zakes Mda
nodes.description: A South African writer, painter, and music composer.

nodes.label: Ways of Dying
nodes.description: A novel about a professional mourner in a violent South African township.

nodes.label: Kōbō Abe
nodes.description: A Japanese writer, playwright, photographer, and inventor.

nodes.label: The Woman in the Dunes
nodes.description: An allegorical novel about a man who is trapped in a sand pit with a mysterious woman.

nodes.label: José Donoso
nodes.description: A Chilean writer, journalist and professor. He lived most of his life in Chile, although he spent many years in self-imposed exile in Mexico, the United States and Spain.

nodes.label: The Obscene Bird of Night
nodes.description: A complex and challenging novel that is considered a masterpiece of the Latin American Boom.

nodes.label: Adolfo Bioy Casares
nodes.description: An Argentine fiction writer, journalist, and translator.

nodes.label: The Invention of Morel
nodes.description: A science fiction novel about a fugitive who discovers a mysterious island where a group of people seem to be living in a perpetual loop.

nodes.label: César Aira
nodes.description: An Argentine writer and translator, and an important figure in contemporary Latin American literature.

nodes.label: An Episode in the Life of a Landscape Painter
nodes.description: A novella that follows the 19th-century German painter Johann Moritz Rugendas on a journey through Argentina.

nodes.label: Roberto Bolaño
nodes.description: A Chilean novelist, short-story writer, poet and essayist.
An epic novel divided into five parts, centered around the unsolved murders of women in a fictional city in Mexico.

nodes.label: Samantha Schweblin
nodes.description: An Argentine author known for her unsettling and surreal short stories and novels.

nodes.label: Fever Dream
nodes.description: A psychological horror novel about a young woman dying in a rural hospital clinic.

nodes.label: Mariana Enríquez
nodes.description: An Argentine journalist and writer.

nodes.label: Things We Lost in the Fire
nodes.description: A collection of short stories that combine horror and magical realism to explore the dark side of Argentine history.

nodes.label: Yuri Herrera
nodes.description: A Mexican writer.

nodes.label: Signs Preceding the End of the World
nodes.description: A novel about a young woman who crosses the border from Mexico to the United States to find her brother.

nodes.label: Magical Realism
nodes.description: A style of fiction that paints a realistic view of the modern world while also adding magical elements.

nodes.label: Postcolonialism
nodes.description: The historical period or state of affairs representing the aftermath of Western colonialism.

nodes.label: Family Saga
nodes.description: A genre of literature which chronicles the lives and doings of a family or a number of related or interconnected families over a period of time.

nodes.label: The Supernatural Mundane
nodes.description: A literary device where fantastical, strange, and magical events are treated as ordinary and commonplace.

nodes.label: Political Allegory
nodes.description: A narrative that serves as an extended metaphor in which persons, abstract ideas, or events represent not only themselves on the literal level, but they also stand for something else on the symbolic level.

nodes.label: Myth & Folklore
nodes.description: The use of traditional stories, myths, and legends within a modern narrative framework.

nodes.label: Surrealism
nodes.description: A cultural movement which developed in Europe in the aftermath of World War I and was largely influenced by Dada.

nodes.label: Identity
nodes.description: The exploration of selfhood, culture, and belonging, often in a shifting, fantastical world.

nodes.label: History & Memory
nodes.description: The exploration of how personal and collective pasts are remembered, distorted, and retold.

nodes.label: Metamorphosis
nodes.description: A change of the form or nature of a thing or person into a completely different one, by natural or supernatural means.

nodes.label: Latin American Boom
nodes.description: A literary movement of the 1960s and 1970s when the work of a group of relatively young Latin American novelists became widely circulated in Europe and throughout the world.

nodes.label: Feminism
nodes.description: The advocacy of women's rights on the basis of the equality of the sexes, often explored through magical or surreal narratives.

nodes.label: New Weird
nodes.description: A literary genre that emerged in the 1990s, which combines elements of science fiction, fantasy, and horror.

What It Means When a Man Falls from the Sky
Perfume: The Story of a Murderer
The Ten Thousand Doors of January
An Episode in the Life of a Landscape Painter
Things We Lost in the Fire
Signs Preceding the End of the World

edges.source: The Particular Sadness of Lemon Cake
What It Means When a Man Falls from the Sky
The Ten Thousand Doors of January
The Particular Sadness of Lemon Cake

commentary: Explore the enchanting world of Magical Realism, where the mundane and the miraculous intertwine.
